docs.lead_paragraph: CLIFFSIDE PARK IN THIS trim little town, many of whose residents fled from nowdesolate parts of the Bronx and Manhattan, a proposal to open a video-game arcade has become a focus of fear and resentment. ''We don't want it on The Avenue,'' meaning Anderson Avenue, the main street, one resident shouted at a recent meeting of the Borough Council, and applause rumbled through the room. The meeting was one of many that have been held - each to a packed house - ever since a businessman, Steven R. Steinberg of Fort Lee, took Cliffside Park to court to try to overturn an ordinance that limits to three the number of games in any establishment. On March 23, Mr. Steinberg applied to the Borough Clerk for a license to open a 40-game video arcade on Anderson Avenue. The application was denied.
